title: Motor industry squeeze continues with new registration plates failing to boost demand
text:
New car sales edged up in September, but despite new registration plates which typically prompt high demand, the rise was below expectations.

Some 343,255 new cars rolled out of factories and on to customers in September, which is up 1.3 per cent from the same month last year, according to the latest survey by the Society of Motor Manufacturers & Traders.

However, that compares to very weak figures last year, when new stricter emission rules sent sales plunging 20 per cent.

Falling demand: New car sales picked up in September, but looking at the year so far, they're still down compared to 2018.

That means that looking at the year so far, new car registrations are actually down 2.5 per cent at about 1.86million, compared to 1.91million in the first nine months of 2018.

The SMMT blamed Brexit and its impact on consumer confidence for the weak figures.

'We expected to see a more significant increase in September, similar to those seen in France, Germany, Italy and Spain, given the negative effect WLTP (Worldwide Harmonised Light Vehicle Test Procedure) had on all European markets last year,' said SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes.

'Instead, consumer confidence is being undermined by political and economic uncertainty.'

Battery electric car sales were up by 122 per cent in the first nine months of the year

The trends continue to be the same seen in previous months: sales of new diesel cars have continued to fall, petrol cars have seen a small increase, while sales of electric cars have made a big jump.

Battery electric car sales were up by 122 per cent in the first nine months of the year, while diesel sales fell by 20.6 per cent. Petrol car sales were up 2.6 per cent.

Sales of plug-in hybrid cars are down by 29.2 per cent after Government grants for new low-emission cars were slashed in October last year - meaning hybrid models are no longer eligible for the scheme.

Motoring groups have warned that the decision will leave the UK struggling to meet targets to reduce vehicle emissions.

Alex Buttle, director of car selling comparison website Motorway.co.uk, said the new reg plate last month didn't give new car sales the significant boost the industry needed.

'Diesel sales fell for the 30th consecutive month, petrol sales were only up marginally and plug-in hybrids continue to suffer from the Government cutting grants at the end of last year,' he said.

'The one green shoot amongst all this negative noise is the strength of electric car sales, with numbers feeling healthy and promising in September. But electric and hybrid sales alone can't yet prop up a car industry that is struggling daily.'

Some 343,255 new cars rolled out of factories in September, up 1.3% on last year

Howard Archer, chief economist at EY Items Club, pointed to a number of 'roadblocks' hitting demand for new cars: ' [...] business and consumer caution over making major purchases, sharply reduced demand for diesel cars amid environmental concerns and stricter emission regulations affecting supply (another round of emissions testing legislation coming into effect on 1 September).

'A further hit to the sector has come from the removal of incentives to buy plug-in hybrid vehicles.'

The SMMT has called on the Government to avoid a no-deal Brexit and agreeing a future with the EU that avoids tariffs and barriers 'that could increase prices and reduce buyer choice.'
